title: Modeling a Non-Periodic Context-Logarithmic Function, Part A

content.description:
On the initial day of sales (<math alttext="t equals 0" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </math>) for a new video game, there were <math alttext="40" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>40</mn></math> thousand units of the game sold that day. Ninety-one days later (<math alttext="t equals 91" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>91</mn></math>), there were <math alttext="76" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>76</mn></math> thousand units of the game sold that day. 

The number of units of the video game sold on a given day can be modeled by the function <math alttext="G" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>G</mi></math> given by <math alttext="G open parentheses t close parentheses equals a plus b ln open parentheses t plus 1 close parentheses" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>G</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mi>a</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>b</mi><mi>ln</mi><mfenced><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mfenced></math>, where <math alttext="G open parentheses t close parentheses" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>G</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced></math> is the number of units sold, in thousands, on day <math alttext="t" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math> since the initial day of sales.
